text: Male voices. A Gregorian chant. We fade in on a crucifix in the apse of the church: a suffering Christ. We cut to a close shot of a small silver cross on a rosar The rosary is held in a man's lap next to a mouse-grey fedora. The light is dim. As we hear a panel sliding, more light wipes onto the ros beads. Wider on the man waiting in the confessional: middle-aged tired.
Son, it is so late.
Yeah, Father, work has just been...
You work too hard.
Nah, I’m just... keepin the place goin’. Anyhow, bless me, Father, for I have sinned. It’s been uh, twenty-four hours since my last confession. I, uh...
Yes my son.
I lied to Connie. Uh, to my wife.
This is very serious.
I know! I promised her I'd quit smoking. She thinks it's bad for me. And I'm trying, but... well, I snuck a couple of cigarettes... Maybe three.
Yes.
It’s hard.
Yes, my son.
—But I’m trying. A clap of thunder.

We are looking, through the rain-pelted windshield of a parked car, at a small, Spanish-style bungalow. The rattl driving rain does not quite cover the sound of drunken fe laughter. There are occasional flashes of lightning outsi and occasional flashes of strobe light in the windows of house. Inside our surveilling car a wrist rolls over to show a w face, streaked with the shadows of dripping rain: 5:00 o'clock. A voice-over begins, authoritatively omniscient—or maybe only sounds so because it is British-accented:

It is 5:00 A.M. The sun is soon to rise. But for Eddie Mannix the day has already begun. Our car’s driver, Eddie Mannix—the man we saw confessing—looks up from his watch to the house. VOICE-OVER (CONT’D) The movie studio for which he works manufactures stories—each its own daylit drama, or moonlit dream. Flash of lightning, crash of thunder, another bout of laughter from the house. Eddie Mannix reaches for his door.

Eddie Mannix emerges from his car—a Packard marking the period as circa 1950. Eddie pulls down his hat brim, turn his collar, and digs hands into coat pockets as he stride through the rain. The strobe light flashes inside the house. The laughter g louder as we approach. Eddie Mannix hesitates only momentarily at the front door tests the knob: unlocked; turns it, enters. VOICE-OVER (CONT’D) But the work of Eddie Mannix cares not for day or night... and cares little for his rest.

On Eddie Mannix at the open door, rain dripping from his fedora, thunder crashing behind him. His eyes narrow in distaste. In the living room a giggling blonde in a milkmaid’s dirn with overloaded bodice bends over a butter-churn. A man with his back to us is peering through a box camera
That's right, darlin’, a little lower... The giggling girl sees Eddie Mannix and stops churning.
Oh, fer—ecce homo! You, here?! The photographer turns to face Eddie: a tall weedy-lookin man with a thin mustache. A sheen of sweat on his brow an upper lip.
The studio has a right to Gloria’s likeness, Falco. Gimme the negatives and things’1ll go easier.
You got it all wrong, Eddie! This is f’private use! Eddie Mannix strides to the camera, pops its back, and pu out a length of film.
Hey! We hear approaching sirens. Falco reacts, bolting for the back door.

Can't a girl take a few pitchas, have a few laughs? Cheez, Eddie, what a old stick-in-the-mud! She giggles. Whap! He slaps her. She looks at him, stunned, then starts weeping. He slaps her again. Outside the sirens wind down and we hear car doors open.
Now you listen to me. You were at a party, you had too much to drink, somebody brought you here, you don’t remember who. You’re going home now and your name is Mary Jo Scheinbrotte. She blubbers:
Okay, Eddie. The front door opens and two uniformed cops enter.
Hello, Mannix, saw your heap outside.
Got a call. Loud, disorderly... He looks around, sniffs. .+. Possible French postcard situation.

Someone was pulling your leg. Mary Jo here was just at a costume party. It’s not really her dirndl. He fishes a wad from his pocket and peels off some bills -.. She wants to contribute something to your pension fund. Sorry to drag you out in the rain.
Well, say, no trouble at all. Cop Two is looking hard at the girl.
Aren’t you Gloria DeLamour?
No no, I'm Mary Jo... somethin’.
Scheinbrotte. Look, Brian... Eddie hesitates, looking at one of the cops who is smokin We hear, distantly but growing louder, a deep thumping so
Can I, uh... bum a cigarette? The thumping sound has grown closer: the tramp of many marching feet. A fanfare on ancient horns as we cut to:

Down the road a Roman legion marches in brilliant Technicolor, the sound of its stamping feet bridging the Cypress trees, regularly planted, stretch along either si of the road to the horizon. The title of the movie fades superimposition:
A Tale Of The Christ The same voice that started the movie now intones:

Ancient Rome! Twelve years into the rule of Tiberius, Rome’s legions are masters of the world, the stomp of its sandals heard from the Iberian peninsula in the west through the halls of the great library of Alexandria in the east! (MORE )

As oppressed people everywhere writhe under the Roman lash... The regularly formed legions in the van now give way to t slaves being whipped along in the rear: .-.- master and slave, freeman and vassal, are united in one compulsory worship: the emperor, Cesar, is Godhead—lord of every man’s body and spirit! For those who will not submit, the galleys, the arenas, even crucifixion await! But there is a new wind, blowing from the east, from the dusty streets of Bethlehem, that will soon challenge the vast house of Cesar—that edifice wrought of brick and blood which now seems so secure! A chariot rolls into the foreground. Its driver is a musc campaign-hardened man with Roman bangs. Beneath his coppe breastplate he glistens with manly sweat. He wears a helm topped by a bright red mohawk bristle, something like an upside-down floorwaxer. He is Autolochus Antoninus. He ga off and smiles. Another man gallops up on horseback and reins in next to This is Gracchus Gregorius, and he too wears the floorwax headwear of the Roman tribune.
There she is, Gracchus. And ah, what a beauty!
Aye, Autolochus! Rome! Suckled by a she-wolf and nurturing us her sons in turn.

Tonight I bathe in Caracalla, and wash away the dust of three hundred miles of Frankish road! To Rome! To Rome ! As he whips the chariot horses into motion we pan off to reveal the hilltop view of Rome before which the weary tribunes had halted.
Yes, to Rome! Glorious center of Cesar’s rule!
A rutted rural road. A man in sandals and simple peasant and using a gnarled walking staff walks through rain, thu and lightning.
But far away, in Palestine...
We are panning off the image to reveal that we have been looking at a screen in a small screening room.

++. another man is coming home. Saul, humble merchant of Tarsus, is about to be struck down by a vision. The continued pan brings us onto the screening room’s one occupant, Eddie Mannix. After a quick furtive look around—meaningless since he is alone—he takes a cigarette from the ashtray next to him and sneaks a puff. SAUL (off) (quavering) What thing is this?

Eddie Mannix strides across the great studio backlot wher technicians mill and actors dressed in the wardrobe of different ages and genres lounge. His secretary Natalie follows at his elbow, struggling to keep up as she consul notepad:

—and Gloria DeLamour has been checked into Our Lady of Perpetual Rest to dry out. You have a 10:00 A.M. with Monsignor O’Reilly at the Wallace Beery Conference Room. He’s bringing Lester Silkwood from the Legion of Catholic Decency and we've also invited Patriarch Vlassos for the Eastern view.
They've read the script?
Roger.
Let's also invite a rabbi, and a Protestant padre of some sort so we can get everybody’s two cents.
Check.
How’s production on “Tucumcari!”?
Principal is on schedule but second unit has been idle in Gallup, New Mexico for four days. Heavy rain.
Forecast?
Not good.
Hnn. Send an insert truck and have ‘em shoot driving plates for “Came the Rain.”
Check.
“Jonah's Daughter” still behind?
Yes, director says the problem is DeeAnna and she’s getting worse.
I know what it is, I’1l drop in on her after my ten o’clock. (pulls back his sleeve to look at his watch) All right, let’s call New York. INT. EDDIE’S OFFICE - DAY Eddie is on the phone.
Nick Schenk’s office.
Hi, Dorothy, Eddie Mannix. The old man in?
Hi, Mr. Mannix, I'll check. Eddie raises his voice:
Natalie, I want the box office on “The Debonaires” and on “Blessed Event.” Can you also— Hastily into the phone:

—yYes, good morning Mr. Schenk... Very well, thank you. Proceeding... Proceeding... “Merrily We Dance” starts shooting today. Beardley Auberon gave us a draft that’s extremely classy. Joan Van Vechten is playing Dierdre, but we need a male lead and we need him now... No, Jack Hogarth is drying out at Cedars... Metro won’t lend us Gable unless we give them the Comiskey Twins... Of course not, I agree... Swell idea but he’s waiting out a divorce in Reno... Whuh—Hobie Doyle?! Do you really think so? After all he’s—he’s a dust actor! The man barely knows how to... talk!... Yes, of course, Mr. Schenk, I agree, but I don’t know if Hobie Doyle, if he has the uh the uh the uh poise in a dinner jacket... Yes, we do need someone pronto... No I don’t. That’s very true. Let me talk to Laurence Laurentz, the director. It could work. Hobie is a very promising idea.

It is a great big boulder.  10. A beard-stubbled cowboy rises from behind its cover to fi his six-shooter. He himself is immediately shot: he grima and releases his gun which swivels around his trigger-fin as he staggers—and drops. He who just shot him: Hobie Doyle, in white Western wear. Eyes narrowed, he gauges the effect of his shot, then rea to the sound of retreating hoofbeats. The other bad men are racing off, firing wildly back in h direction. Hobie adroitly twirls and holsters his gun.

Whitey! The white horse placidly cropping the grass several yards away flicks its ears and looks over. It nickers and shuff to face away from Hobie as he runs to it. He vaults its r and man and animal are off. Hobie riding. A mounted bad man falls in behind him—a bushwack. This pursuer begins to fire. Hobie rocks forward on Whitey, low to his neck. He reache down to grab the saddle, one hand on either side. He push himself up into a handstand atop the racing horse. An oncoming tree limb hooks his knees and he swings up an around as his horse races on unridered. When he loops bac around the tree limb his six-shooter is at the ready and fires on the swing at the oncoming horseman. The bad man clutches his chest and falls from his horse as Hobie swin up again. Hobie uses his upward inertia to gracefully execute a tra artist dismount from the branch. His drop toward the grou is neatly intercepted by the bad man’s galloping horse, H plops into its saddle. He reins in the snorting beast and it rears he fires his six-shooter into the air in an expression of pure brio. He then twirls and holsters his calms the horse with a pat on the neck, and leaps aground claps dust from his yoked white shirt.
And cut. A man in sunglasses rises from a canvas chair next to a camera attended by men in creased hoist-up pants and whit shirts and ties.
Great, Hobie.
I kin do the handstand smoother if ya gimme another shot atter.
We've got four good ones Hobie, and Whitey is tired. An assistant trots up to Hobie with a small tin. Hobie ta it and loads a chew into one cheek.
Okay, you’re the bossman. If that’s lunch ammo grab me a plate a beans.
Hobie, the studio wants you to escort Carlotta Valdez to your premier tonight.
But she warn’t in the pitcher.
Well that’s what they want.
But she warn’t in the pitcher.
Well, it’s some publicity thing.
Ah don’t git it.
Well, the studio says you’re bringing Carlotta Valdez. You're her escort.
But she’s Carlotta Valdez. Hit don’t make sense. She warn’t in the pitcher.
Who was in the picture? Hobie thinks.
Whitey.  12.
Well Eddie Mannix says you're escorting Carlotta Valdez. Guess they’re changing your image. INT. COURTYARD OF SESTIMUS AMYDIAS —- DAY

They sit in the courtyard of a Roman villa—several togaed senators and their robed wives—on chairs carved of cedar draped with fine silks. Incongruous entrance: a man in sunglasses wearing a white open-necked shirt. He looks here and there. He raises a megaphone. 1ST A.D. All right, kids, it’s Rome, you're over at this guy’s house for a revel, and here comes Antoninus. Llllots of energy!
Roll ‘em. A short, togaed extra holding a lyre lurks by a tabletop which sits platters of succulent feastings, and one goble furtive look around.
Camera speed.

Sound speed. The extra produces a cellophane packet from the folds of toga. After another quick glance around he opens the pack flap and taps its powdery contents into the goblet. He hastily crumples the packet and exchanges a significan look with: Another extra, holding a turkey leg nearby. This man is b with fringe hair upcombed to make corner hair-vees. The first extra is startled by: 1ST A.D. What’re you doing at the table of viands?!  13.
++. Huh? 1ST A.D. You're supposed to be reclining, with the lyre!
Yeah, sorry, I uh— 1ST A.D. Recline with the lyre!
Yes, sir.
We set there? Background set? 1ST A.D. Don’t sit on the pediment! Recline! Relaxed, festive!
Yes sir. 1ST A.D. (projecting) Set! (narrows his eyes and points at the extra now reclining, hissing as he leaves) I got my eye on you.
Fountain! Water starts to gurgle as the courtyard fountain comes to life.

Background! The extras talk among themselves in pantomime, displaying Roman gaiety and deep involvement in their silent conversations. Some sip at goblets, some nibble at rich comestibles. Occasionally, a guest tips his head back for peal of silent laughter. Our extra strums his lyre not in pantomime but sounding i the same arpeggio, over and over again, separated by the beat of silence.  14.
And action! Autolochus strides in. A senator rises to greet him.

Autolochus! I had heard rumors of your return to Rome! We are close on the reclining extra with the lyre. Autolochus, standing before him, is only a pair of foregr feet in sandals with leather lace-ups twining the calves. leather creaks as he talks:

More than rumors, noble Sestimus! The reclining extra looks steeply up at Autolochus. His p of-view shows Autolochus mostly backlit; we see off the s and up into the greens. Autolochus, with great aplomb, swipes the goblet from the table. I see that you are the same worshipper of Bacchus. What gaiety! There is still truth in the adage, “What pleasures cannot be found in the villa of Sestimus Amydias, cannot be found in Rome!” (brings the goblet to his lips but stops with a thought) But seriously. There is talk that the Senate will send our legions out again—and this time not on a short march to Gaul. What truth to these mutterings, Sestimus? The reclining extra and the extra with the turkey leg exchange a worried look.
The matter is to be taken up in the Senate. It seems that there is unrest in Palestine.

Palestine! That backwater! They’1l hardly be sending the Sixth Legion to that godforsaken patch of desert!  15. Hearty male laughter. Autolochus ends his laugh and raise the goblet to his lips. Just before drinking—he is taken by another gust of laughter. The two extras exchange a look. The reclining extra hugs lyre and worriedly arpeggiates. When Autolochus’s second access of laughter peters out he raises the goblet again—and now takes a long draught.

Holding for a dissolve... still laughing... holding... and... cut. Autolochus lowers the goblet, panting, and wipes meadfoam from his mouth with an armful of sleeve. The extras too relax. The director enters: Sam Stampfel, of manly middle-age.
Fine, boys, that was fine. We'll move on to the brasier scene.
Yeah? Was I okay on “What truth to these mutterings?” I felt a little—
Nah, fine, we move on. Brasier scene, twenty minutes.
Popping over to my dressing room. (to Script Supervisor) Got the pages for the brasier scene? The Script Supervisor points to a spot on the page as he hands it over.
They changed “passion” to “ardor.”
What? I liked passion. It’s strong. “Passion.”

The Script Supervisor shrugs a what-can-I-tell-you? Autolochus wanders off, muttering:  16. AUTOLOCHUS (CONT’D) Not so, Ursulina... My ardor is yet as warm as the embers of this brasier... The extra with the lyre exchanges another look with the b extra. He indicates with a jerk of the head that they sho follow Autolochus who, as he examines his script, is cros the long dark expanse of soundstage, toward a distant glo exit sign.

Outside now, the short extra cautiously leans and cranes peek around a soundstage corner. The bald extra is next t him. His point-of-view: huge stucco soundstages range into the distance. The only person about is a small receding Autolochus Antoninus, his sandals scuffing the road and s banging his thigh as he walks. He still looks at the scri we hear his distant muttering:

Such is my greeting after three months’ sojourn in Gaul?... Not so, Ursulina... My ardor is yet as warm- He stops momentarily, swaying. He extends a hand to stead himself against the exterior wall of a soundstage. After moment, he moves on, somewhat uncertainly. EXT. BAIRD’S DRESSING ROOM —- DAY

head_text.subj: A STAR ON A DRESSING ROOM DOOR

text: A slow pull back reveals the name above the star: BAIRD WHITLOCK. Muffled, from within, we hear Autolochus/Baird Whitlock:

Not so, Ursulina. My ardor is yet as warm as the embers of this brasier... The embers of thish brasier... Goddamn, that’s tough. Yet as warm as the embersh of this brasier... Not so, Urshulina... The continuing pull back reveals the two extras standing either side of the door. The bald one nods at the short o  17. At the nod, the short extra knocks.
They’re ready for you, Mr. Whitlock. The two men stand tensed. After a short beat of clomping inside, the door swings sl up. Baird stands, swaying, giving the two men a glassy st
(slurred) Not so, Ursulina— He pitches forward into the ready arms of the togaed men.
Eddie Mannix strolls and speaks. His audience is a four- person convocation of clergy sporting different hats, cap robes, beards.

Gentlemen, thank you all for coming. I know you have parishes, flocks and temples making enormous demands on your time. But I’m sure you appreciate also that great masses of humanity look to pictures for information and uplift and, yes, entertainment. Now here at Capitol Pictures, as you know, an army of technicians and actors and top-notch artistic people are working hard to bring to the screen the story of the Christ. It’s a swell story—a story told before, yes, but we like to flatter ourselves that it’s never been told with this kind of distinction and panache.
Perhaps, sir, you forget its telling in the holy Bible. A wry smile from Eddie Mannix.
Quite right, Padre. The Bible of course is terrific. (MORE )
But for millions of people, pictures will be their reference point for the story—the story’s embodiment... (groping) the story's...
Realization. Eddie points an aiming finger at the Minister, saluting h choice of words.
Realization.
You “realize,” of course, that for we Jews, any visual depiction of the Godhead is most strictly prohibited.
(dismayed) Oh.
But of course, for us, the man Jesus Nazarene is not God.
(brightening) Ah-ha.
Who plays Christ?

A kid we're all very excited about, Todd Hocheiser, wonderful young actor we found in Akron, Ohio, in a nationwide talent hunt. But Hocheiser is seen only fleetingly, and with extreme taste; our story is told through the eyes of a Roman tribune, Autolochus Antoninus, an ordinary man skeptical at first but who comes to a grudging respect for this swell figure from the East. And Autolochus is played by... He permits himself a satisfied smile. «+. Baird Whitlock.  19. Murmurs of appreciation from the assembled and one low “that’s-something” whistle.
Well, he is certainly a great talent.

Now Hail, Cesar! is a prestige picture, our biggest release of the year, and we are devoting huge resources to its production in order to make it first-class in every respect. Gentlemen, given its enormous expense, we don’t want to send it to market except in the certainty that it will not offend any reasonable American, regardless of faith or creed. Now that’s where you come in. You’ve read the script; I wanna know if the theological elements of the story are up to snuff.
I thought the chariot scene was fakey. How is he going to jump from one chariot to the other, going full speed? A frozen beat as Eddie frames an answer.
Uh-huh, well, we can look at that. But as for the, uh, religious aspect—does the depiction of Christ Jesus cut the mustard?
The nature of the Christ is not quite as simple as your photoplay would have it.
How so, Father?
Well, it is not the case simply that Christ is God, or God Christ.
You can say that again! The Nazarene was not God!  20.
He was not not-God.
He was a man!
Part God.
Nossir!
But Rabbi, we all have a little bit of God in us don’t we?
Well...
It is the foundation of our belief that God is tri-partite.
Father, Son, Holy Ghost.

And Christ is most properly referred to as the Son of God. It is the son of God who takes the sins of the world upon himself so that the rest of God’s children, we imperfect beings, through faith, may enter the kingdom of heaven.
So God is... split?
Yes. Eddie nods. .-. And no! Eddie frowns.
There is unity in division.
And division in unity.
Not sure I follow, Padre.  21.

Young man, you don’t follow for a very simple reason: these man are screwballs. (to the others) God has children? What, and a dog? A collie maybe? God doesn’t have children. He’s a bachelor. And very angry.
He used to be angry!
What, he got over it?
You worship the god of another age!
Who has no love!
Not true! He likes Jews.
God loves everyone!
God is love.
God is who is.
This is special? Who isn’t who is?
But how should God be rendered in a motion picture?
God is not in the motion picture!
Then who is Todd Hocheiser?
Gentlemen, maybe we're biting off more than we can chew. (MORE )
We don’t need to agree on the nature of the deity: if we can focus on the Christ, whatever his, uh, parentage. My question is: is our depiction fair?
I’ve seen worse.
So I can put you in the plus column, Patriarch? The Patriarch gives a musing nod. Eddie turns to the minister. ... Reverend?
There is nothing to offend a reasonable man.
Father?
The motion picture teleplay was respectful and exhibited tastefulness and class.
Who made you an expert all of a sudden? Eddie turns to the Rabbi.
«+. And what do you think, Rabbi? The rabbi shrugs and affects mildness.
Eh. I haven’t an opinion.
Eddie Mannix emerges, dabbing at sweat.
How'd we do?  23.
Mm. What’s up?
Can’t find Baird Whitlock. He left the set over an hour ago, said he was going to his dressing room but he isn’t there.
Out on a bender? Am I crazy, middle of the day?
You're not crazy, but no. I checked the Til Two, Dan Tana’s, Rusty Scupper. No soap.
Home, maybe? Called his wife?
Yep.
What’d Laura say?
He’s not home, he’s never home, he’s a louse, try one of his chippies.
Called that script girl, what's her name—Francie?
Check.
Any of the gals missing from the set?
Nope.
Well... (looks at his watch) Gone an hour? We won’t worry yet.  24.

Baird Whitlock’s head lolls in the foreground, waggling w the motion of the vehicle. His body—he is still in wardro leather skirt and a breastplate over his white tunic—stretches away into the background: he is laid out, unconscious, on a paddy-wagon style bench. At the end of bench in the background we see, cropped and soft, a goon double-breasted suit, his forearms on his knees, smoking.
Hollywood Boulevard. The truck roars by. Its paneled side says “Al’s Linens.”
Hobie Doyle is pulling up in a chauffeured car. The guard looks in the back window and is surprised to see the West star.
How ya doing, Hobie.
Lo there, Scotty.
They got you shooting on the lot?
Wul, Mr. Mannix pulled me off the Western, says I’m doin’ a movie on a soundstage. They built a drawing room.
Ya don’t say.

A bathing beauty in a sequined mermaid suit swims free-ar but wriggle-tailed, constrained by her fake nether-parts. From our underwater perspective we hear burbling music.  25. After a beat of her swimming solo many bodies shoot down the water to join the mermaid, entering foreground and background in headfirst dives that leave bubble-trails. T beauties swim loops and then wave themselves back up towa the surface, smiling. But the mermaid remains. She approaches a foreground sunk treasure chest. Atop its gold coins sits a silver crown which the mermaid seems to recognize as her own. She reac for it, smiling-but as she does so a shadow travels over near-to-deep. And then great jaws hinge closed behind her capturing her-and the lens-in the black belly of a whale. We linger in black. Water surface slowly emerges from the black: we are high above the water now, looking straight down. With our change in perspective the music now blares undistorted. In the tank below us the bathing beauties spin in a forma that goes through constant kaleidoscopic change. In the center of the circle formed by the beauties a dark shape begins to resolve itself: something is surfacing amid the girls. It is the whale. As it breaches amid the swimmers its blowhole, directly beneath the lens, spouts. Jetting wate rises toward us. Something else is rising, borne up by the jetting water: sundae-cup coach of sorts. In it rides the mermaid, triumphantly ascending. Her ascent ends high, high, high above the tank. The spouting water recedes but her sundae cup remains magical suspended in air. She opens the cup's gate-door and looks down at the water far, far below. As a drum roll builds she prepares to div And does dive. She splashes into the water and is lost from view. A suspenseful hold, on nothing. And now she emerges from the water, rising again, now ona pedestal and now wearing her silver crown, recovered in w offscreen neptunian rite who can say. The mermaid is proud of herself, proud of her crown, prou her bathing-beauty minions-but then pride evaporates. Som internal struggle. She seems to be getting angry.  26. She yanks off the crown and tosses it away, squalling:

Wardrobe! The music slows to sludge and stops. The mermaid flops into the water and splashes awkwardly toward the side of the tank, her fluke spanking the surfa as cowed bathing beauties make way and an off-mike voice yells “Cut!”

A minute later: she is leaned back on a canvas chair, her face set in a grimace, a gurgle of effort building in her throat. Two men behind hold her in place, each with an ar looped over her shoulder and under an armpit. After a long straining moment:

With her cry there is a rubbery thwop-sound of suction gi way, and we cut to the reverse: A stagehand staggers back, holding the now freed bottom h of her scaly mermaid outfit. He tips it backfin-upward an little water dribbles out. The mermaid is now wearing scaly top-half of her outfit o Coming from beneath it, below her waist, is a conventiona Catalina swimsuit. She feels tenderly at her stomach as a assistant director enters. A.D. Gas again, ma’am?
MA‘AM? MISS? Am I married? A.D. No miss.  27.
No. Yeah, sure, gas again. (Eddie approaches; she indicates him) Ask him, he knows. Okay, scram.
How are you, DeeAnna?
How am I. Wet. And I don’t think I’'ll fit in the fish-ass after this week.
Well, we should have the water ballet in the can after tomorrow; in the nightclub scene wardrobe'’11 have a gown for you that's more... forgiving. Um... any more thoughts about who you might marry?
HAH! Ain't doin' that again! I had two marriages, and it just cost the studio a lotta money to bust’em up.
Well we had to have those anulled— one was to a minor mob figure and—
Vince was not minor!
And Buddy Flynn was a bandleader with a long history of narcotic use.
Yeah yeah, they were both louses, yes, and that’s what I’m sayin’. A third louse ain’t gonnna do me no good.
We've offered you some very suitable, clean young men.
Pretty boys, sap, and swishes! You think if there was some good steady reliable man I wouldna grabbed him?  28. EDDIE i” Well, what about Arne Seslum? He is the father, isn’t he?
Yeah yeah.
The marriage doesn’t have to last forever. But, DeeAnna, having a child without a father would present a public relations problem for the studio. The aquatic pictures do very nicely for us, and—
So you strap on the fish-ass and Marry Arne Seslum!

The pictures do well for all of us. And it’s a tribute to you: the public loves you because they know how innocent you are. Let me see if Arne is open to, um... matrimony. You're sure he’s the father?

Yeah yeah. Absolutely. He’s the father, yeah. Pretty sure. Eddie has been nodding and making to withdraw. The last sentence gives him pause but DeeAnna, ready to get back t work, projects: «+. Okay Maxie, bring me my ass back!

The “Al’s Linen’s” truck rattles by. We hear the crash of surf. Up ahead, on the right side of the road is a weathered si for “Rudy’s Fish Shack—500 yards.” Just before the sign i turn-off to the left, onto an unpaved and rutted road. Th truck makes the left turn.  29.

People in formal-wear lounge, chatting. Hobie Doyle enters stiffly in a tuxedo. He tugs at his collar. A distinguished-looking man, middle-aged, well dressed bu not in wardrobe, hastens to greet Hobie. He is the direct Laurence Laurentz.
My dear boy, you look wonderful, how do you feel?
Well this here collar is a little tight.

No no, nicely fit, looks a marvel, just takes a little getting used to. Now you enter here, Hobie, having just seen Biff’s valise in the foyer—in spite of Allegra’s claim that he hasn’t been to the house.
I’m sweet on Allegra.
Indeed you are.
But I seen Biff’s grip.
Indeed you have. And so here we find you haunted by unspoken suspicions.
Haunted. By Biff’s grip.

By his valise, yes, but then here is Dierdre, (indicates actress on couch who coldly examines Hobie—a veteran with no patience for the rookies) «+. harboring deep feelings for you, and sensing opportunity.  30.
Dierdre.
Dierdre, yes. So at her importuning, you join her on the couch, and conversation ensues. Hobie is concerned.
(troubled) So now she’s gonna importune, Mr. Laurence?
Laurentz.
Oh, I’m sorry. She’s gonna importune? Is that somethin’ I should, uh, be concerned about—
She'll simply ask you to join her on the couch, is all I mean to say, and conversation ensues.
Okay, I gotcha.
Very good, very good, let’s try one shall we?
Sure, I'll give her a go.
Wonderful, splendid. (turns away but turns back with a thought) The only thing I would suggest is, before your first line, you respond to her line with a mirthless chuckle.
A mirthless chuckle.
Yes, given your unspoken suspicions about Allegra, a mirthless chuckle.  31.
Okay, Mr. Laurence, I'll give it a—
Laurentz.
Oh, gosh, I’m sorry, Mr. Laurentz. I‘ll give it a shot.

A clapper-boy ID’s and whacks a slate on “Merrily We Danc Laurence Laurentz’s voice calls “Action!” Those assembled in the parlor come to life in a pantomime civilized conviviality, chatting and laughing. Hobie enters, an uneasy backward glance referring perhaps the unseen grip.

Oh, Monty! Come join me on the divan! Briefest who-me confusion from Hobie. With a quick recove he manages a fairly casual saunter to the couch where he plants himself—not close to Dierdre. She slides over to close the gap between them, and she is now all warmth and sympathy. Her voice is musical and upper-crust:

It seems Allegra's a no-show, which is simply a bore, but I can partner you in bridge. (reacting to him) Why the pout? Gazing at the floor, Hobie gives a short loud laugh that sounds like a Heimlich-expulsion. A flinch from the actre Hobie’s grin abruptly drops, and, still gazing at the flo
Would that it were sooooo... simple.

A beat, the actress looking at him, Hobie looking at the floor. The beat grows longer... longer... Voice of Laurence Laurentz: “Cut!”  32. We cut to Laurence Laurentz sitting in his director’s cha mouth slightly open, staring without expression as he tri to frame his notes. He abruptly rises and walks into the set to join Hobie.
Very good—wonderful in fact. But let's try it a little differently this time—
Sure.
—let’s try, well let’s see, first of all why don’t we dispense with the mirthless chuckle.
No mirthless chuckle.
No, no need, really—it was a bad idea, bad directorial—my fault, overthinking the thing.
Well if you say so, but I’m happy to do another—maybe try her one more time—I mean if you want that chuckle I sure wanna give her to ya—
No no no, completely unnecessary under the circumstances, I think the audience can to that extent read your thoughts, and will assume your mirthlessness.
Okay, you’re the bossman, Mr. Laurence.
Laurentz.
Oh, gosh, I’m sorry, Mr. Laurentz—  33.
Also, let’s try, this time, actually looking at Dierdre as we speak, looking into her eyes, and speaking our line with a certain... ruefulness. Hobie nods agreement.
Ruefulness, okay.
Yes. Because it’s not so simple. Not so simple as she suggests.
Okay.
Your feelings are not so simple.
Nawsir. Okay.
Splendid.

A clapper-boy ID’s and whacks a slate on “Merrily We Danc identifying the scene number and Take 2. Laurence Laurentz’s voice calls “Action!” Those assembled in the parlor come to life in a pantomime civilized conviviality, chatting and laughing. Hobie enters.
Oh, Monty! Come join me on the divan! Smoothly this time, Hobie joins her on the sofa. When he he is still not close; she slides to him. The same music her intonation:

It seems Allegra's a no-show, which is simply a bore, but I can partner you in bridge. (reacting to him) Why the pout?  34. Hobie looks at her, somewhat shifty-eyed, not comfortable with the eye contact.

(rueful) Would that? (slight beat; sad head- shake) It were soooo... simple. Voice of Laurence Laurentz: “Cut!” Hobie looks hopefully to the approaching Laurence Laurent The director, feeling his look, puts on a smile.

Good, very good. Wonderful, in fact. Let’s try, this time... He balls a fist and brings it to his mouth and stares at floor, thinking. Hobie waits, gazing up at him. At length: LAURENCE LAURENTZ (CONT’D) All right, let’s try this, your line, just say it as I say it, say your line exactly as I’m about to. Just as I’m about to do.
Sure, okay. Beat to focus attention, and then:
(rueful, and British- accented) Would that it’were so simple.
Would that ih twuuuuuuh, so simple. Laurence Laurentz stares at him.
My dear boy, why do you say that—why do you say, “twuuuuuh”?
Well you said, say it like I say it.  35.
Yes but—
Would that it twuuuuuuh, so simple.
Would that it’were so simple.
Would that ih twuuuuuh, so simple.
Would that it’were so simple.
Okay, I’m tryin to do that, Mr. Laurentz—
Laurence.
I thought—um, a minute ago it was Laurentz—
We can use Christian names, my good dear boy. Laurence is fine—
Okay.
—yust as I call you Hobie. So, “Would that it’were so simple.” Trippingly.
Would that it twuuuuh—
You seem to be lingering, it’s interminable—
Oh gosh.
—I'm wondering when it’1l end, the “were,” and we shouldn’t have to wonder, should we, we should be marching right along to “so simple”!  36.
Would that ih... (after hesitating, rushed) twersasimple. Twersasimple.
Would that it were so simple. Not “simple!” Just... (relaxed) simmple.
Simmmple. Simmmple. Gosh, I can’t seem to cinch m’saddle up on this’n, Larry—
Larry! Good God, Christian names, yes, but not Larry.

We are looking down into a hidden box cove of the Pacific Ocean, rugged and secluded. Surf pounds into the teeth of jagged rocks just offshore. Nestled in the canyon just ab the cove’s tiny beach is a modernist octahedral beach hou The “Al’s Linen’s” truck is parked where the beach road e just in front of the house. The goon from inside the truc now has Baird Whitlock in a fireman’s carry, taking him t the house’s front door. We jump down close—the surf louder here—as the goon knock The knock brings furious dog-yapping from inside the hous We are close on Baird’s head upside-down against the big man’s back. Just past the two men the door swings open, a as the big man steps in he turns to negotiate Baird’s bod through the doorway, Baird’s sandaled legs sweeping towar us. There are two men waiting inside. The one at the door is middle-aged, with sad eyes: He is John Howard Herman. The deeper man is the room is heavy-set, and in a cheap s not freshly pressed. Near him, a springer spaniel frantic spins in place yapping, excited to have visitors.

Quiet, Engels!  37. When the goon has passed with his Roman cargo the sad-eye John Howard Herman swings the door toward us, filling the lens. INT. EDDIE’S OFFICE - DAY On the other side of Eddie’s desk is producer Walt Dubrow
Stall?! For how long? What do I tell the director?

That we’re looking for him. But we don’t want it in the gossip columns—Baird on a bender or ina love nest or wherever we end up finding him. As far as the set is concerned it’s business as usual. Tell the A.D. Baird is out briefly with a high ankle sprain.
Fine, but what do we shoot without him? We got the brasier scene up this afternoon.
Could you get through it shooting around him?—Maybe use his stunt double, Chunk Mulligan.
Chunk can’t act.
Get the writer to trim his speeches.
Well, maybe, but then what? All we got left is the final scene—Autolochus’s speech at the feet of the penitent thief. Eddie grimaces.
Uh-huh.
It’s the emotional climax of the entire picture! (MORE )
We have to see that Autolochus has absorbed the message of the Christ!
Yeah, I can see that.
We need Baird’s star power, his charisma. A wave of Eddie’s hand communicates the ineffable:
Sure, his emotional, uh—
This can’t be faked! This is the heart and soul of the picture!
I understand—
End of the movie, we can’t give that speech to some—some—some Roman schmoe!
Yeah, yeah I got it. But his benders can last a day or two—what does it cost to shut down?
Plenty. You know how big the picture is, we’re on Stages 5 and 14, if we’re carrying everybody in the last scene who’s up on crucifixes that’s three-forty an hour hardship pay eight hour minimum—
Yeah yeah. (his phone buzzes; he punches the button) Not now.
—not to mention we lose Todd Hocheiser to Fox at the end of the week.  39.

Shoulda made him exclusive; who knew. (another buzz from the Phone) Not now! NATALIE’S VOICE It’s Mr. Laurentz, Mr. Mannix! I can’t stop him! The door bursts open and Laurence Laurentz storms in. Nat has trailed him to the door, where she hovers.
It’s all right, Natalie. Okay Walt, lemme know—
Mannix, I won’t have it! For two decades the name “Laurence Laurentz” has meant something to the public!
What’s on your mind, uh... Laurence?
Hobie Doyle cannot act!
Hobart Doyle is one of the biggest movie stars in the world.

On horseback! But this is drama, Mannix—real drama, an adaptation of a Broadway smash! It requires the skills of a trained thespian, not a rodeo clown. I begged you for Lunt! Natalie has been hesitant to butt in:
Mr. Mannix, I’m sorry but—you wanted me to make sure you didn’t miss your lunch at the Imperial Gardens. You never told me who with.  40.
Right. (looks at watch, grimaces) Nuts. Look: no one wants to see Lunt. We’re not recasting; this came from Mr. Schenk himself: it’s Hobie Doyle. Is the boy game?
Oh, he’s game. And gamey!
If he needs help it's your job to help him. I’1l have a talk with Hobie and take a look at what you've shot—but right now I’ve got a lunch.

The pounding of surf fades up, the sound close but somewh muffled by interior perspective. We are fading up wide on Baird Whitlock, lying on his bac still unconscious. He lies on a patio chaise lounge made thin plastic tubing stretched across an aluminum frame. W are in a storeroom, the chaise being the room’s only piec furniture. A muffled ding-dong from the front of the house. We hear springer spaniel, stirred by the bell to yapping. With much plastic-squeaking Baird rolls onto his side and nestles his head into the chaise’s tubing-upholstery. In sleep he murmurs:
What truth to these mutterings, Sestimus... He subsides to snoring.

The sad-eyed man, John Howard Herman is opening the front door to several visitors. The first visitor enters: murmu greetings, solemn handshake. Another man, another sober handshake.  41. Then an elderly man in tweeds clutching his pipe, the greeting for him especially deferential. Then a man with briefcase; he sets it down so that he may greet by means hug. He picks up the briefcase, makes way for the next ma A counter separates the entryway from a small kitchen. In the man we saw shushing the dog when Baird was brought in carefully cutting the crusts off of finger sandwiches and stacking them on a platter. As the dog yaps in a frenzy of delight at all the visitor the man reacts without looking up:
Quiet, Engels!
A gong stings the cut to the interior of this Chinese restaurant. Arthur Fung, a grave-looking man in a dark suit and conservative tie, greets Eddie Mannix.
How pleasant to see you, Mr. Mannix, your table is right over here.

Thank you, Arthur. They splash through a curtain of beads to approach a boot which another man sits, a drink with an umbrella before h an ashtray and an Imperial Gardens matchbook next to it, cigarette in his hand. He rises to shake.
How ya doing, Mannix.
Mr. Cuddahy.
Mix a hell of a mai-tai. I like this place. The men seat themselves facing each other.
Sorry to keep you hanging—it’s a tough decision.  42.

Nothing to apologize for—we said the offer was on the table for a week. Cuddahy has noted Eddie eyeing his cigarettes. He picks u the pack and offers with a hitch of the wrist that sends cigarettes nosing out of the top of the foil.
Go ahead.
Nah, I’m... I’ve been trying to...
The deadline was tomorrow, but, frankly, we were surprised not to get a quick yes. I just wanted to see if there was some impediment we could help with, or if something in the offer isn’t clear?
The offer’s very clear. And very generous.

We want to make it easy for you to say yes. Look Mannix, we need a guy with your talents in management, problem-solving. And you need to think about the future. Lockheed is booming—it’s reflected in the offer we made you. Everyone is riding in airplanes, and we're moving into jet airplanes. It’s a new age, Mannix, and we’re part of it; the industry you're in—what’s the future there? What happens when everybody owns a television set? Will they still be going to pictures every week?
Well, we—
I don’t mean to denigrate; I’m sure the picture business is pretty damned interesting. But it’s also pretty frivolous, isn’t it? Aviation is serious; serious business, serious people. (MORE )
You won’t be babysitting a bunch of oddballs and misfits, shouldering a lot of crackpot problems from people who—
Look, we have some kooks, sure—

Course they’re kooks, it’s all make- believe! (quick grimace and smile; he leans back) I told myself I wasn’t gonna badmouth the competition, and looka me. Sorry, Mannix, I’1l stick to what we’re about. Lemme show you something. (digs in a pocket) Ever heard of the Bikini Atoll?
What?

It was a test site, couple of rocks in the South Pacific—till a few weeks ago. Then we blew the Aitch- erino. Not supposed to be telling you this. (hands Eddie a picture) The real world. Hydrogen bomb. Fusion device.
Armageddon.
And Lockheed was there. We had a— He cuts himself off. A splash of the bead curtain.

Call for you, Mr. Mannix. The waitress, in a red embroidered sheath dress, is enter with a telephone. She plugs it in. As she leans to set it the table Cuddahy swipes the picture from Eddie’s hand wh it was exposed to view.
Thank you... Hello?... And he has it now?... No, have him stay on set, I'll go to him. (MORE )
(slams down the phone and rises) Sorry, Cuddahy, work emergency. Still do work there, for the day anyway. (grabs his hat, calls back over his shoulder) You make a good case. I’1l let you know.

There is a dull clunk and we are close on Baird Whitlock, opens his eyes. Wider: Baird in his centurion’s wardrobe reclining on the beach chaise. The sound of ocean outside. The clunk has punctuated an ongoing machine-hum which continues, cycling louder and softer, its loudest approac always punctuated by a clunk. The lawn chair makes tacky noises as Baird disengages fro it. He stiffly sits up. He gazes stupidly about, looking the depth of the room: where am I? He twists to look behind himself, lawn chair crackling, a does a modest take: out the window is the Pacific Ocean. Another clunk and receding machine hum. Baird registers t noise, gets to his feet and walks to the door. It is clos He reaches for the knob. He tries the knob. It turns. He through the door.

The main room, in which we saw Baird being brought in and mysterious visitors entering. It is now empty except for middle-aged woman with a bandana tied Aunt-Jemima style o her head. She vacuums. Each forward pass of the machine e with its clunk against the wall. The woman looks up, and shows no particular interest in B despite his breastplate and leather skirt. She turns off vacuum.
You one of the Hollywood people?  45. Baird stares at her, considering all the possible answers Finally:
... Maybe.

They’re in there. A jerk of her head indicates a hallway. She fires up the machine again. Baird looks down the hallway. From one of its rooms, muff male laughter. He goes cautiously down the hall, the vacuum sound fading away, Male voices fading up. One door is ajar. Baird cautiously bumps it open further. Another round of laughter is interrupted as all turn to l at the Roman-attired man in the doorway. Most of the interrupted party are seated; there are a couple of overf standees; several men smoke cigarettes, one smokes a ciga the tweedy elderly man is sunk back in an easy chair smok a pipe. The springer spaniel leaps and twists and yaps, excited b the new arrival.
Quiet, Engels! Again, this does nothing to quiet the dog. Baird looks fr man to man. John Howard Herman, the man who greeted the o arrivals at the door, the apparent host, waves Baird in.
Please! Enter! All are welcome! Baird cautiously enters. One man vacates a seat for him. Baird cautiously sits. His scabbard catches on the chair prompting chuckles from some of the men.
Those things are a nuisance! A nearby man leans over to help him adjust it. Baird sits back.
Thank you. Uh...  46. The men look to him, waiting for him to bring out his thought. Herman helps:
Wondering where you are?
Yeah. The dog has subsided and comes over to sniff at Baird’s sword.
Malibu. We’ll have sandwiches in a minute. Tea?
.-. Tea. Well. Okay. Okay. And... and—
And what's going on?
Yeah.
Well, we've just read the minutes and Allen was about to bring up new business.
So... I missed the minutes.
I wouldn't worry about it.
They're usually pretty boring.
Uh-huh. And—what kind of meeting—exactly—
Well it’s not a “meeting,” so much as a, a—what should we say?
It’s a—more of a, a study group.
And you're studying... ?  47.
Oh, all sorts of jolly stuff.
History.
Economics.
Same thing, isn’t it—history, economics?
Don’t you agree? All are looking at Baird.
Well... I’m... I’m not really a student of history.

Someone reaches in to take a sandwich off the offered platter. Wider: Baird sits back with the finger sandwich. It is minutes later and the respectful quiet has now given way the relaxed clatter of people eating, laughing, having si conversations.
Thank you. So man is... split?
Well, man’s functions are split. There’s the little guy, the regular Joe, who works for a living. He’s the body, uh, body politic. Then there’s the brain—the boss, the owner—
The boss is not the brain!
No no! The boss is parasite!  48.
Well, it’s true that the boss doesn’t work, but he has a function in the system— Baird looks from man to man, as at a tennis match. He controls the means of—
—production, sure, but that’s not a function, that’s, that’s—

Parasitism! On the body! On the body politic! Of the regular Joe! It’s— A throat clearing. Everyone instantly quiets. All look to the old man in twe who is just lowering his pipe. Having claimed the floor h now speaks with non-argumentative authority.

Man is unitary—a simple economic agent. Man’s institutions are split, expressing contradictions that must be worked through. And they are worked through in a causative, predictable way: history is science. This is the essence of the dialectic. Click! A sallow thin young man with heavy beard shadow ha just snapped a picture of Baird. A sickly smile at Baird then he turns to face someone else in the room and—click!—takes a picture.

See, if you understand economics, you can actually write down what will happen in the future, with as much confidence as you write down the history of the past. Because it’s science. It’s not make- believe. Like Professor Marcuse says. There’s no mystery.
We don’t believe in Santa Claus! Hearty guffaws.  49. Click! The photographer is edging around the group, continuing his picture-taking.
Another finger sandwich? More tea?
But if I—sure, thank you—if I follow this, correctly, you— (eye caught by man with camera) Who’s he?
Mr. Smitrovich takes pictures for our newsletter. The sallow picture-snapper smiles again at Baird.

Our understanding of the true workings of history gives us access to the levers of power. Your studio, for instance, is a pure instrument of capitalism. As such it expresses the contradictions of capitalism, and can be enlisted to finance its own destruction.
Which is exciting! It can be made to help the little guy, the regular Joe—
The body politic!
Shutup!—help the little guy, even though its purpose is to exploit the little guy.
Okay, so you guys are for the little guy.
Well—for the little guy, against—it doesn’t matter, history will be what it will be, and we already know what it will be, but—yes, we’re for the little guy, aren’t you?  50.
Are you joking? Me, for the little guy? Of course I’m for the little guy! Is this guy a comedian?
And you would act. To help the little guy.
Act?
Praxis.
What?
Act.

Yeah yeah, act yeah, but—sorry fellas, this is good stuff, but—I oughta get back to work, they must be goin nuts—can we cut it off and pick it up right here at the next study session? The clatter subsides to quiet. Cautious looks are exchang among the men. Herman, gazing at Baird and nodding, thinking, finally fr his opening:

Okay, well, see: I’m afraid it’s not that simple. As we cut wide on the room, the same voice that narrated sandal epic “Hail, Ceasar!” at the beginning of our movie returns, distinguished, British-accented, authoritative y plummily comforting:

And so Baird Whitlock found himself in the hands of Communists... Herman starts to silently explain things to Baird. The sc of cozy bonhomie is framed by the elemental vastness of t ocean outside.  51. VOICE-OVER (CONT’D) Meanwhile, far from the crashing surf of Malibu, Eddie Mannix, torn from his lunch with the Lockheed man...
A montage of Eddie, a tiny, solitary figure, striding thr the canyons between enormous sand-colored soundstages.

-.. hurries back to the vastness of Capitol Pictures, whose tireless machinery clanks on, producing this week’s ration of dreams for all the weary peoples of the world. Closer on Eddie as he enters the small door of a soundsta The light above the door is flashing red.
High-ceilinged darkness and quiet. A man posted at the do hisses at Eddie, entering:

Hey, numbskull, didn’t you see the “rolling” 1i—Oh, I’m sorry Mr. Mannix. Can I help you find someone? We have been hearing the distant, echoing voices of two actors, a hoarse-voiced man and a silken-voiced woman. Their voices bump up full as we cut to the periphery of t scene being shot around a great flickering brasier. An ac in centurion’s wardrobe identical to Baird’s has one hand half-covering his face as the other arm stretches out as to repel the gaze of a revealingly clad slavegirl.
Autolochus! Why do you present yourself in my chambers in such humble fashion?  52.

Do not look upon me, Ursulina. The fires of the brasier of Sestimus latterly burned my face, though the unguents of Arkimideus promise shortly to undo the damage. In the foreground Eddie leans in to Walt Dubrow, watching scene, and whispers:
Walt.

Eddie! He fishes a twice-folded paper from his pocket. Eddie holds it up so that he may read by the flickering g light that simulates brasier flames. Typewritten: We have your movie star. Gather $100,000 and await instructions. Who are We? The Future.
You know that my love is for you not for your station, and neither does it care for the transitory blemishes that now mark your visage. Eddie gives a low whistle at the contents of the note.
And my ardor for you is yet as warm as the embersh of thish bra—goddamnit—this brazher. I’m sorry, goddamnit.
Cut!
Eddie and Walt emerge from the soundstage onto an exterio set with thick temple columns.  53.
Somebody slipped it under my door some time after we broke this morning.
Mention it to anyone?
Nope. Eddie gazes, unseeing, down the row of columns as two wor tip the farthest one, striking it.
Okay, let’s keep it that way. (realizes where he is) We shot this out?
Chasing the money-lenders from the temple? Yeah, last Friday. Eddie nods, thinking.

What do you think they mean, “The Future”? Walt answers with a beats-me shrug and headshake. Eddie g back down at the note and moseys off—but turns back with bright finger-cock at Walt: «+. Chunk sounded good in there! INT. EDDIE’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Eddie bangs through a door that says:
Natalie, could you please get me Stu Schwartz, Accounting?
Eddie strides in as the phone on his desk buzzes:  54. NATALIE’S VOICE Stu Schwartz on two.

Stu, how are you. I need some petty cash... Hundred thousand. I’m sorry, did I say “petty”?... With the handset shoulder-clamped to his ear he stoops an pulls on attaché case from the legwell of his desk and pl it on the desktop and pops the clasps and starts emptying .+. Yeah, well it’s a long story and I’1l tell it to ya sometime. You have that much in the office?... How much space’1l that take up?... Okay, this might do it. I'll be over in a minute. As soon as he disconnects, Natalie edges into the office.
Thora Thacker just came in, wonders if you have a moment. Eddie winces.
Thora Thacker. Tell her I’m stuck on a call. I’1l leave through the patio.
As Eddie marches past the executive offices with his empt attaché case, a tall red-haired woman arcs in to march alongside him. He winces.
Call didn’t take so long, then.
Yes—no—fast talker. What can I do for you, Thora?
Well, I'll be fast too. I only wanted to notify you as a courtesy that I’m running my story on Baird Whitlock.  55.
Yeah? What story?
The story. I have a credible source and I’m going to run it, and I think you know what story I mean.
I have no idea—there’s nothing going on with Baird—I would know, wouldn’t I?
Don’t play dumb, Eddie, I’m talking about... (dramatic pause, dramatic delivery) “On Wings as Eagles.” This stops Eddie in his tracks. He stares at Thora, wide- and shaken. Finally:
What?! She gives him a knowing look and a confirming nod.
Running it tomorrow.

First of all—first of all—first of all—there’s nothing to that story. I’ve heard it, it’s been around forever, and it’s never been confirmed. And secondly—you can’t print that! Even if you could print it you couldn’t print it. And you wouldn’t want to, Thora, it’s beneath you.
The facts are never beneath me.
People don’t want the facts, they want to believe. That’s our great industry—mine, and yours too. They want to believe that Baird Whitlock is a great star, and a good man.  56.
You're admitting he isn’t.
No, I’m saying he is, though it’s beside the point. There’s nothing to it, nothing to the gossip.

head_text.subj: I AM NOT A GOSSIP COLUMNIST

text: No no, of course not—
Don’t confuse me with my sister!
Hardly. But look—do you have to run it tomorrow?
It’s my entire column. I’m happy to talk to Baird for comment, but it’ll have to be this afternoon.

Baird is unavailable right now. Wait one day. A chirping hoot from Thora. Eddie grimaces and lowers his voice confidentially: Thora, wait one day and I’1l give you a true story for tomorrow's column. A little something—about Hobie Doyle.
My readers don’t care about Hobie Doyle. He wears chaps.
Do they care about Carlotta Valdez? They’re sweet on each other. You should see the two of ‘em together, peas in a pod.
Trade the story of my career for a puff piece on Hobie Doyle? I don’t think so.  57.

You're not trading anything, you’re waiting one day on a story that’s years old. Give me a day, I can let you talk to Baird and show you your story’s the bunk.
